0.00.text:
Translator: Helena Bowen
Reviewer: Denise RQ

16.96.text: But a pen is a simple thing, isn't it?

20.12.text:
It doesn't have a battery
or a motherboard.

22.82.text:
It doesn't require a service plan
or a satellite orbiting the Earth

28.63.text:
It's never smarter
than you are, which I like.

33.20.text: And if you were to drop it in water,

35.30.text:
or any distance higher
than your own knee on a hard surface,

40.19.text:
In fact, purchasing
an insurance plan for it

42.92.text:
would be, well, silly,
and slightly ridiculous.

46.28.text:
Yet, this simple pen has shaped
the very world in which we live.

51.50.text:
It has recorded the discoveries
of scientists and inventors.

56.66.text:
It has charted the course
for nearly every explorer

60.26.text:
who has braved the open ocean
or explored the vast terrain.

65.58.text: Wars have begun and ended at its wave

70.96.text:
and the doctrine of nearly every one
of the world's religions

78.38.text:
It has recorded the genius
of composers and artists alike,

84.20.text:
and more lovers have succumb
at its tip than any of Cupid's arrows.

91.34.text:
You see, more than a pen,
this is a vital part of our humanity.

95.75.text:
It is the facilitator to genius,
the strongest weapon in war time,

100.30.text:
the baton passed
from one generation to the next,

104.80.text:
the needle on the Richter
scale of our hearts,

108.97.text: and the connection between God and man.

112.20.text: Yet, for the first time in history,

114.81.text:
the value of this amazing tool
hangs in the balance.

119.56.text:
With 41 out of 50 states
no longer requiring handwriting

123.37.text:
to be a fundamental part
of their curriculum,

126.30.text: like everything else in our culture,

128.43.text:
we declare its value by what we teach
or do not teach our children.

133.92.text:
Yet I stand before you today
not only as an advocate for the pen,

137.89.text: but as your advocate as well,

139.89.text:
for while the hand empowers the pen,
the pen empowers the man.

144.39.text:
So empower yourselves today
and write this down.

148.74.text:
Use this and you will develop
not one but three forms of literacy.

155.41.text:
The first form of literacy
is that of historical literacy.

159.59.text:
You see, we have a vast
chronology of handwriting

163.89.text:
because man has been writing by hand
for literally thousands of years.

168.70.text:
In every culture, time period, and nation
has had its own form of handwriting,

175.28.text:
and they are each as unique
as one individual's is to another's.

179.86.text:
I could regale you with a vast background
on each one of these forms,

185.62.text:
but let me bring things
a little closer to home

188.04.text: and bring you more quickly up to speed.

190.89.text:
This is America's first style
of penmanship

197.58.text:
It is called Spencerian script,
created by Platt Rogers Spencer

201.88.text:
in the middle of the 19th century
when he was only 13 years old.

206.66.text: Not only did this boy create

208.33.text:
one of the most dynamic forms
of penmanship known to man

212.43.text:
he also had a beautiful philosophy
and even theology behind his handwriting.

217.38.text:
You see, he believed that God,
being the originator of all beauty,

221.30.text: had instilled his beauty in nature,

223.96.text:
so if Spencer could take
his cues from nature,

226.59.text:
then he would have the beauty of God
in his own handwriting.

230.02.text: Not bad for a 13 year old.

233.26.text: So, this is one of the pieces that I did,

235.81.text: not only as a nod to Spencerian script

240.29.text:
but to show the place
from which it was inspired.

243.50.text:
He was inspired by the flowing lines
he saw in the streams by his house,

247.43.text:
the gentle lean of the wheat
blowing in the wind,

250.30.text:
and the rolling clouds
over mountain peaks.

254.17.text:
Spencer's form was not only genius
in its appearance,

258.32.text:
but it was a thing of brilliance
in function as well.

263.17.text:
the way that we typically write is
we plant our palm on the side of our hand,

267.42.text:
and we use a whole variety
of horrible pen grips,

270.34.text:
and we write using
mainly finger movement.

273.66.text:
This puts stress on all
of the smallest joints, muscles, tendons,

279.12.text:
and in the end, it results
in what we know as writer's cramp.

282.96.text:
Back in the day,
Platt Rogers Spencer devised

285.47.text:
that his handwriting should be written
with the knuckles up towards the ceiling

289.21.text:
using muscular movement,
which is movement at the wrist,

291.92.text:
and whole arm movement
for those larger graceful curves,

295.60.text:
so you could write all day long
and never get writer's cramp.

300.29.text:
There were others that followed
in Spencer's pen-strokes.

306.20.text:
regarded as the greatest
ornamental penman who ever lived.

309.32.text: He built on Spencer's fundamental form

311.79.text:
to bring us some of the most
dynamic scripts known to man,

314.74.text:
one of which is said to have inspired
the Coca-Cola logo,

318.75.text:
one of the longest standing,
most dynamic logos of all times.

323.17.text:
Or this man, F.B. Courtney,
the pen wizard,

326.95.text:
so-called because of the magic
created at the tip of his pen.

331.54.text:
It was said that Courtney,
whenever he taught,

334.34.text:
would go into a room and fill a chalkboard
with museum-worthy flourishing and script,

339.40.text:
and then, at the end, he would
take a piece of chalk in each hand,

343.33.text:
stand at the chalkboard and sign his name
simultaneously in opposite directions

351.51.text:
Now I know what you're saying,
"Jake, this is all well and good,

354.81.text:
but I'm afraid my penmanship
has sailed and sunk."

362.88.text: "I'm sorry, I was just not born

364.67.text:
with the natural facilities
that these masters were."

367.55.text: Well, let me encourage you a bit,

370.11.text:
and possibly make you
feel worse about yourself.

373.96.text: This is J.C. Ryan, the handless penman.

377.66.text:
He was a man born without hands
who made his living in penmanship.

387.22.text: You see, these are the heroes of our past,

389.92.text:
these are the builders
of our handwriting heritage.

393.59.text:
Newton said we only reach great heights
"by standing on the shoulders of giants".

398.73.text:
I tell you that my hand
only moves so gracefully

401.73.text:
because I have rehearsed
the strokes of masters.

405.61.text:
Use this and you will develop
intellectual literacy.

411.63.text:
In college, I actually got 
my degree in psychology,

417.02.text:
largely because I did not think
I was going to make it as an artist.

420.57.text:
Of course, I practiced my artwork
and my handwriting incessantly,

425.18.text:
so much so that I gained a reputation
among my professors

429.05.text: who were handing around my essay tests

432.22.text:
saying that they looked like
the Declaration of Independence.

443.79.text:
we actually studied how handwriting
helped develop the brain.

448.15.text: I took copious and beautiful notes.

453.16.text:
And what we discovered
when we studied this

455.73.text:
was that during the different
tactile movements of doing handwriting,

460.26.text:
the brain is actually
engaged in more areas,

463.74.text:
and the information
is engrained into the brain.

466.97.text:
The same was not found to be true
with typing, however,

470.32.text:
which does not involve the same type
of differential tactile movement.

475.21.text:
Handwriting was also found to be
incredibly helpful in small children

479.33.text:
who were learning to read,
because by forming the individual letters,

482.85.text:
they had a deeper understanding
of the anatomy of each one

485.73.text:
and were therefore able to recognize it
when it came time to read it on the page.

490.98.text:
Moreover, cursive was found to be
even more beneficial to the brain.

496.57.text:
Researchers and scientists have done
brain scans on children learning cursive

502.34.text:
and found that the different
parts of the brain which are engaged

505.78.text:
are similar to those adults typically use
when writing and doing higher reasoning.

512.28.text:
The screen went blank
when the kids were typing

515.19.text:
because it didn't involve
the same type of tactile movement.

520.09.text: So, let me point out the fact

522.67.text:
that not only has technology brought us
this amazing information,

528.11.text:
but in this case, it stands
as the champion of handwriting.

533.26.text: One thing we need to stop doing

534.81.text:
is putting technology and handwriting
in opposing corners.

539.19.text:
People often assume that with
my old ideals and ancient art forms

544.08.text:
that I am somehow stuck in the past,
and therefore, I must hate technology.

549.27.text:
Let me assure you,
I do not hate technology.

554.18.text: In fact, I am a proud Apple user.

556.38.text: I have an iPhone, iPad, iMac, Macbook.

559.63.text:
I have my own website, Twitter,
Instagram, and Facebook accounts

563.90.text:
and I drive around in a horseless 
carriage like everybody else,

567.10.text:
so don't try and tell me
that I'm stuck in the past.

572.25.text:
Beyond acknowledging the fact
that we are in a modern age,

575.50.text:
I do believe that typing
is a very fundamental tool

579.26.text: that children do need to learn.

580.97.text:
However, they should not be learning it
at the expense of handwriting.

592.47.text:
You see, schools are leaning all the time
more and more so on technology

596.20.text:
to help move kids down the conveyor belt
of the educational system,

601.29.text:
but what we need to do
is be a good steward of both

603.99.text:
and listen to what
our technology is telling us

606.59.text: and pick up the pen and keep writing.

609.23.text:
You see it is not technology
that is the direct enemy of the pen,

612.58.text: it is our dependency on technology.

616.74.text:
The greater we grow
our dependency on technology,

619.15.text:
what we may soon find
is that we've created

621.68.text:
the most technologically advanced way
of creating illiteracy.

627.95.text:
Use this and you will develop
creative literacy.

633.37.text: The handwriting is such a personal act

636.91.text:
and is it any wonder
when you can actually use

640.54.text:
your own signature interchangeably
with your finger print.

646.59.text:
You see writing captures
more than our thoughts,

649.03.text:
it records our emotions; it even captures
our personalities down on paper.

655.66.text:
We all know the power 
of a handwritten note.

659.31.text:
Ever since I was a kid, one 
of the first people who inspired me

662.56.text:
to start working on my handwriting
was my own mother.

666.53.text:
She used to pack my lunch 
for me every day in school,

669.92.text:
and she would always put a napkin in there
with her beautiful handwriting on it.

673.91.text:
My whole day could fall apart,
I could fail the spelling test,

676.89.text:
be picked last for kickball,
and go down into a lunchroom

679.96.text:
with a lunch lady screaming her way
out of a hair net at wayward children

683.64.text:
who were throwing milk cartons through
the air like hand grenades on D-Day

688.53.text:
and I would open up my lunch box
and I would see that note

692.17.text:
on top of my peanut butter and jelly
sandwich and a bag full of Cheetos

696.00.text: and the whole world went still.

699.83.text: Some things just stick with you.

704.24.text:
And so, this love for the pen
was nurtured so early in life.

709.83.text:
When I picked up my first calligraphy pen,
I was disappointed at its quality

714.96.text:
and disappointed at the general lack
of available tools on the market.

719.77.text:
So I took it upon myself
to learn how to create my own pen.

727.71.text: I taught myself how to use the lathe

733.85.text:
and I started shaping
a whole wide variety of exotic hardwoods,

741.76.text:
contouring their shape perfectly
to fit my pen grip.

747.81.text: I would also add little bits of ornament,

750.85.text:
dynamic shape to give flare
and romance to them.

755.06.text: Then, I would fit my own nibs,

759.37.text: I would mix my own ink,

761.66.text:
until finally I was able
to put pen to paper.

773.36.text:
I have since created hundreds of pens
for penmen around the world

779.65.text: so that the art of the pen might thrive.

785.76.text:
Since I made my first calligraphy pen
almost eight years ago,

789.69.text:
it has marked the greatest growth spurt
for me as an artist.

793.99.text: In 2011, I became the youngest person

797.25.text:
to ever achieve 
the title of Master Penman,

800.25.text:
and I stand with only 
11 others in the world.

810.70.text:
As the last requirement
to become a Master Penman,

813.28.text: you have to make your own certificate.

821.00.text:
So here it is, this is my certificate
executed on calf skin vellum.

826.80.text:
It has six styles of calligraphy,
two types of gold leaf gilding,

834.56.text:
I carved the pen that I wrote it with
and the frame it went in out of mahogany.

844.81.text: Now, those last two were not required

852.00.text:
but I wanted them to be expressed
in the context of my certificate,

856.00.text: and I don't get out much, so...

860.82.text:
Once I learned the discipline
of this fine art,

863.30.text:
I started incorporating it into
the other mediums that I had done before,

867.63.text:
finding that the written word
gave such powerful life to my artwork.

873.39.text:
I learned the disciplines of flourishing
and the rules which govern its script

878.67.text:
and started changing
the whole world around me.

882.60.text:
In one instance, at least, I created
this two dimensional design

886.86.text:
and got the opportunity
to translate it through wood carving

892.30.text:
into this four-foot slab of mahogany,
entirely carved by hand.

900.86.text:
This is done with one 
of my handmade calligraphy pens.

903.94.text:
It's a portrait of Christ that is
done in one continuous stroke.

909.07.text:
It's a spiral which starts
at the center of his nose,

912.33.text: it goes outward around itself 175 times.

918.25.text:
and gets thicker and thinner
to create shadow and highlight

921.31.text:
and then, in the end,
evens out to a perfect oval.

925.08.text:
So you see, more than a form
of writing or communication,

930.91.text: this is an art form for me.

933.51.text: As an artist, and as a master penman,

936.88.text:
it is my goal to see that it lives on
to see the dawn of a new generation.

943.75.text:
because as I have shown you,
it is a powerful link to our past?

948.33.text: It is the aid to our life-long learning,

951.94.text:
and it is the conduit through which
self-expression might flourish.

956.65.text:
May we always keep it
ever close to our hearts.
